Print This Page
Cambridge City
MA

Resolution
RES 2024 #292

Resolution on the death of Luke Bailey Santos.

Information

Department:City Clerk's Office, MMSponsors:Vice Mayor Marc C. McGovern
Category:Death Resolution

Attachments

Version History
  1. Printout

Body

WHEREAS:

The City Council was deeply saddened at learning of the death of Luke Bailey Santos, on February 20, 2024, at the age of 20: and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke was born on April 4, 2003, in Newton, Massachusetts to Albert Santos and Allison Bailey; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke grew up in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and attended the Graham and Parks School, the Vassell Lane Upper School and graduated from Cambridge Rindge and Latin High School in 2021; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke was full of exuberance and passion, had a natural charisma from an early age that drew people into his circle, and he impressed all those who knew him with his independent spirit, love of nature, sharp analytical mind, boundless curiosity, and inspiring ambition; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke’s passion for life and service led him into organized politics after an 8th grade field trip to the Massachusetts State House sparked his interest and led him to print his own business cards, don a suite and tie, and venture back to the State House on his own to introduce himself to whomever he could; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke’s calling to make a difference for others led him to working on various political campaigns by the age of 14, including, being an important part of the Massachusetts Democratic Party, where he supported the planning and execution of the 2018 Democratic State Convention, played a critical role in the campaigns of Sam Gebru for Cambridge City Council, Marc McGovern for Cambridge City Council, Ayanna Pressley for U.S. Congress, Joe Kennedy III for U.S. Congress, Elizabeth Warren for U.S. Senate and President, Stephanie Everett for Massachusetts State Representative, and Tarik Lucas for Newton City Council and after moving to New York City to attend Fordham University, Luke immediately jumped into the political life of his new home and worked on the New York City Council races of Julie Won, Yusef Salaam, and Christopher Bae; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

By the time Luke turned 20, he had built a political resume that rivaled many people more than twice his age. Luke’s analytical mind, diligent work ethic, and passion for learning everything about electoral politics were quickly recognized by many seasoned political operatives and elected officials across Massachusetts and beyond; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke’s passion for public service was limitless, extending beyond his two driving interests of affordable housing and social justice; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

When the COVID-19 pandemic began, Luke founded and led the Mask Up Project, where he organized the making of over 800 face masks from repurposed fabric and distributed them for free to local shelters, organizations, and residents in need; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Luke’s light brightened our lives for only 20 years, but his impact on those who knew him and all who benefited from his commitment to social and economic justice will carry on forever. Luke tragically and unexpectedly passed away on February 20, 2024, taken from the world far too soon with so much left to accomplish and experience; now therefore be it

 

 

RESOLVED:

That the City Council go on record extending its deepest sympathies and condolences to Luke’s parents, Albert Santos and Dr. Allison Bailey, his siblings Grace and Sam, his stepfather, Dr. Joseph Audette, his grandparents, Rita and Gary Bailey, and Alicia Santos, his many aunts, uncles and cousins, and his extensive network of friends and admirers; and be it further

 

 

RESOLVED:

That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of this resolution to Luke Bailey Santos’ family on behalf of the entire City Council.
